awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel for 2024 USENIX Conferences FAST 2024 and NSDI 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
The USENIX Association presents conferences at the forefront of computing innovation and research that build collaborations between researchers and practitioners from industry, government, and academia. These events provide educational, mentorship, and networking opportunities of very high value to graduate students in the computer sciences who attend. To help increase the representation and participation of these students, this proposal provides funding to assist approximately 20-25 US-based graduate students to attend each of the following events:

22nd USENIX Conference on File and Storage Technologies (FAST 2024)
21st USENIX Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI 2024)

The knowledge shared and advanced at these conferences has practical and meaningful application to many tools used in daily life, as well as to the ethical, cultural, and social ramifications of computing technology. This grant allows the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conference and extends the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers from across the country. USENIX is an open access organization, and all research and results presented and published at these events are freely available to the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This grant provided travel funding to assist US-based students to attend two USENIX events in early 2024, specifically the 22nd USENIX Conference on File and Storage Technologies (FAST '24) and the 21st Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI '24). 

Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field and exposes students to leading-edge work. This grant made possible the participation of graduate-level students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences and extended the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers. 

FAST '24 took place February 27-29, 2024, in Santa Clara, California. It brought together storage-system researchers and practitioners to explore new directions in the design, implementation, evaluation, and deployment of storage systems. NSDI '24 took place April 16-18, 2024, also in Santa Clara, California. NSDI '24 focused on the design principles, implementation, and practical evaluation of networked and distributed systems. Both events consisted of technical presentations, including refereed papers and poster sessions. 

Students at each event were offered activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including a student meetup, mentorship opportunities, poster sessions, and receptions. 

Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants had two components: 1) registration costs and 2) expenses. USENIX covered registration costs by providing grant recipients with a code providing full registration at the reduced student rate. For the expense portion, USENIX provided payment to assist with costs related to travel and lodging. Variations in the rates offered depended on how far a student needed to travel and the number of nights they requested for lodging. We confirmed that grant recipients registered and attended the relevant event before completing payments. 

The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:

  • Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics,

  • Conference participation (e.g., presenting a poster),

  • Pertinence of supporting statement outlining the applicant’s research,

  • Application history, prioritizing first-time applicants and those not receiving a grant in the previous twelve months,

  • Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events,

  • Students from historically underrepresented communities and minorities,

  • Class level and financial need.

The NSF funding provided under this award allowed us to substantially increase the number of students we could support with grants for FAST '24 and NSDI '24. This support was instrumental in enabling a total of 54 grants for students to participate in FAST '24 and NSDI '24, making a significant difference in their academic and professional development.

  • For FAST '24, USENIX received 24 grant applications from students and awarded 23 grants. The NSF funds of $25,000 covered 18 of these grants. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a US university and those who flew to the venue traveled on a US carrier. There were 179 attendees at FAST '24, which included 46 students. FAST '24 was held entirely in-person, with no virtual attendance options. 

  • For NSDI '24, USENIX received 66 grant applications from students and awarded 31 student grants.  The NSF funds of $25,000 covered 20 of these grants. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a U.S. university. The recipients who were not local traveled on a US carrier. There were 365 attendees at NSDI '24, which included 79 students. NSDI '24 was held entirely in-person, with no virtual attendance options.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/06/2024
Modified by: Catherine Bergman

This grant provided travel funding to assist US-based students to attend two USENIX events in early 2024, specifically the 22nd USENIX Conference on File and Storage Technologies (FAST '24) and the 21st Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI '24).


Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field and exposes students to leading-edge work. This grant made possible the participation of graduate-level students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences and extended the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers.


FAST '24 took place February 27-29, 2024, in Santa Clara, California. It brought together storage-system researchers and practitioners to explore new directions in the design, implementation, evaluation, and deployment of storage systems. NSDI '24 took place April 16-18, 2024, also in Santa Clara, California. NSDI '24 focused on the design principles, implementation, and practical evaluation of networked and distributed systems. Variations in the rates offered depended on how far a student needed to travel and the number of nights they requested for lodging. We confirmed that grant recipients registered and attended the relevant event before completing payments.


The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:

Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events,




Students from historically underrepresented communities and minorities,

The NSF funding provided under this award allowed us to substantially increase the number of students we could support with grants for FAST '24 and NSDI '24. This support was instrumental in enabling a total of 54 grants for students to participate in FAST '24 and NSDI '24, making a significant difference in their academic and professional development.




For FAST '24, USENIX received 24 grant applications from students and awarded 23 grants. The NSF funds of $25,000 covered 18 of these grants. There were 179 attendees at FAST '24, which included 46 students. FAST '24 was held entirely in-person, with no virtual attendance options.






For NSDI '24, USENIX received 66 grant applications from students and awarded 31 student grants. The NSF funds of $25,000 covered 20 of these grants. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a U.S. university. The recipients who were not local traveled on a US carrier. There were 365 attendees at NSDI '24, which included 79 students. NSDI '24 was held entirely in-person, with no virtual attendance options.
